Agent A’s report is correct in principle. MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 requires that calls to the <string.h> functions (strstr, strchr, strcmp, snprintf with %s, etc.) must not cause accesses beyond the bounds of the object pointed to by the pointer parameters. In the shown code several string functions are used on the pointer filename (and also on key via strcmp): strstr(filename, ".."), strchr(filename, '/'), strchr(filename, '\\'), and later the use of filename with %s in snprintf. The code only checks filename != NULL; it does not validate that filename points to a NUL-terminated array or otherwise prove the buffer bounds. If there is no external, documented guarantee that filename is a properly NUL-terminated C string (provided by the callback API), these calls could read past the object’s bounds and therefore would violate Rule 21.17.

If the surrounding API (e.g. the HTTP library that invokes process_upload_data) guarantees that filename and key are NUL-terminated strings, then using these functions is acceptable under MISRA provided that guarantee is documented and relied upon. Otherwise the code should be changed to avoid unbounded string scans (for example, by using length-aware routines or by validating/truncating inputs to ensure NUL termination) to satisfy Rule 21.17.
